facts.text: Appellants are the owners of a building situate on Dashaswamedh Road in Varanasi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the owners of a building situate on Dashaswamedh Road in Varanasi, the ground floor of which companysisted of two shops separated by a partition wall and an arch in between.

facts.text: Respondent took possession of both shops.

facts.text: On August 8, 1954, appellants at request of respondent removed partition wall and replaced arch by iron girders.

anchor.surface_text: On August 8, 1954, the appellants at the request of the respondent removed the said partition wall and replaced the said arch by iron girders enabling the respondent to have a companypact and companymodious unit.

facts.text: About mid-October 1954, respondent started making alterations without consent of appellants.

facts.text: By notice dated February 22, 1955, appellants terminated the tenancy and called for vacant possession.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however seems to have relied on Hymen and Anr. v. Rose where relief against forfeiture of lease was granted, inter alia, on the ground that the alterations carried out by the lessee had not done any harm to any one and the reversioner was in no way injured. But the question there was one of interpretation of a covenant contained in the lease and whether the alterations constituted waste.

arguments.claim: Wates v. Rowland illustrates structural alteration distinct from repairs

anchor.surface_text: As an illustration as to what a structural alteration means some assistance can be had from the decision in Wates v. Rowland and Another though it was a case of interpretation of s. 2 1 a of the Increase of Rent and Mortgage Interest Restrictions Act, 1920.

J. construing a covenant against alterations in a lease, made a distinction between alterations intended for the proper user of leased premises and material alterations observing that some limitation must be put on the word alteration in such a covenant

holdings.text: Clause (c) of section 3(1) of the U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 is disjunctive and provides two independent grounds for eviction without the District Magistrate's permission: (i) where the tenant has materially altered the accommodation, or (ii) where the construction is likely to substantially diminish its value.

anchor.surface_text: In our view clause  c  of section 3  1  cannot bear the companystruction suggested by Mr. Desai. The clause is companyched in simple and unambiguous language and in its plain meaning provides that it would be a good ground enabling a landlord to sue for eviction without the permission of the District Magistrate if the tenant has made or has permitted to be made without the landlords companysent in writing such companystruction which materially alters the accommodation or is likely substantially to diminish its value. The language of the clause makes it clear that the legislature wanted to lay down two alternatives which would furnish a ground to the landlord to sue without the District Magistrates permission, that is, where the tenant has made such companystruction which would materially alter the accommodation or which would be likely to substantial diminish its value.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and unambiguous language uses 'or' in disjunctive sense; ordinary rule of construction applies absent absurdity or defeat of legislative intent; conjunctive reading would exclude material alterations without diminution and vice versa, contrary to legislative purpose to cover both contingencies.

holdings.text: The alterations made by the respondent-tenant materially altered the accommodation within the meaning of clause (c) of section 3(1), as they altered the form and structure of the premises by lowering the floor level, front door, staircase, chabutra, and cutting the plinthband.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the alterations, there is numberdispute that the respondent carried them out without the permission of the appellants. The question then is whether they were such that they materially altered the accommodation as provided by clause  c . Without attempting to lay down any general definition as to what material alterations mean, as such a question would depend on the facts and circumstances of each case, the alterations in the present case must mean material alterations as the companystruction carried out by the respondent had the effect of altering the form and structure of the acconunodation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dispute on lack of permission; alterations changed form and structure (lowering floor by 1.5 ft, door, staircase, chabutra); ordinary meaning of 'material alterations' is important changes to front or structure; distinguished from repairs; analogies from Wates v. Rowland and Bickmore v. Dimmer; case-specific, no general definition.

holdings.text: The appellants are entitled to a decree for eviction of the respondent without permission of the District Magistrate under section 3(1)(c), and the High Court's judgment is set aside restoring the lower court's decree.

anchor.surface_text: In this view the companystruction carried out by the respondent must fall within the mischief of clause  c  and entitles the appellants to maintain their suit for eviction without the permission of the District Magistrate and to a decree for eviction. Both the companytentions urged by Mr. Desai must therefore fail. In our view, the High Court was in error in allowing the appeal of the respondent only on the ground that the said alterations did number appear to have caused any harm to the premises or that there was numbersuch finding by either of the two companyrts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alterations fall within clause (c) as material; High Court erred on disjunctive interpretation and requiring damage finding; concurrent lower court findings accepted; even absent damage or diminution, material alterations suffice.

precedents.citation: Hymen and Anr. v. Rose 1912 A.C. 623

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however seems to have relied on Hymen and Anr. v. Rose 1 where relief against forfeiture of lease was granted, inter alia, on the ground that the alterations carried out by the lessee had number done any harm to any one and the reversioner was in numberway injured. But the question there was one of interpretation of a

precedents.cited_proposition: alterations not causing harm or injury to reversioner do not warrant forfeiture of lease
precedents.cited_holding: alterations did not constitute breach of covenant against waste as no harm done and user not prohibited, relief against forfeiture granted upon offer to restore premises

precedents.citation: Wates v. Rowland and Another 1952 2 Q.B. 12

anchor.surface_text: As an illustration as to what a structural altera- 1 1912 A.C. 623. tion means some assistance can be had from the decision in Wates v. Rowland and Another 1 though it was a case of interpretation of s. 21 a of the Increase of Rent and Mortgage Interest Restrictions Act, 1920. The Court of Appeal there found that whereas substitution

precedents.cited_proposition: laying additional concrete bed is a structural alteration or improvement, not mere repair
precedents.cited_holding: whereas substitution of tiled floor for rotten wooden floor is repair under s.21(a), laying additional concrete bed provides better substratum and is structural alteration

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Bickomore v. Dimmer 2 Lord Cozens-Hardy L. J. companystruing a companyenant against alterations in a lease, made a distinction between alterations intended for the proper user of leased premises and material alterations observing that some limitation must be put on the word alteration in such a companyenant and that it companyld number be applied to a change in the wall paper of a room or to the putting up of a gas-bracket, or the fixing of an electric bell, though in fixing it some holes might have to be made in the wall and that the companyenant should be limited to something which alters the form or structure of the building.

precedents.cited_proposition: covenant against alterations limited to material alterations changing form or structure of building, not minor changes like wallpaper or fixtures
precedents.cited_holding: distinction between alterations for proper user and material alterations; alteration covenant applies only to changes altering form or structure, not trivial ones like changing wallpaper or fixing bell

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree passed by the High Court and restore the judgment and decree passed by the First Additional Civil Judge, Varanasi, whereby he directed the eviction of the respondent.

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly interprets clause (c) of s. 3(1), directly addressing the issue of interpretation of s. 3(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: In our view clause  c  of section 3  1  cannot bear the companystruction suggested by Mr. Desai. The clause is companyched in simple and unambiguous language and in its plain meaning provides that it would be a good ground enabling a landlord to sue for eviction without the permission of the District Magistrate if the tenant has made or has permitted to be made without the landlords companysent in writing such companystruction which materially alters the accommodation or is likely substantially to diminish its value. The language of the clause makes it clear that the legislature wanted to lay down two alternatives which would furnish a ground to the landlord to sue without the District Magistrates permission, that is, where the tenant has made such companystruction which would materially alter the accommodation or which would be likely to substantial diminish its value.

We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree passed by the High Court and restore the judgment and decree passed by the First Additional Civil Judge, Varanasi, whereby he directed the eviction of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the alterations, there is numberdispute that the respondent carried them out without the permission of the appellants. The question then is whether they were such that they materially altered the accommodation as provided by clause  c . Without attempting to lay down any general definition as to what material alterations mean, as such a question would depend on the facts and circumstances of each case, the alterations in the present case must mean material alterations as the companystruction carried out by the respondent had the effect of altering the form and structure of the acconunodation.
